commit.message:
Gracefully handling errors

The following improved error handling is added. This is needed to gracefully
operate with the ESDM (https://chronox.de/esdm) in edge conditions:

- handle write system call failures by deallocating and allocating the
entropy source which includes closing and opening the file descriptor to
/dev/random

- use proper variable types (ssize_t vs size_t) to avoid implicit casts

- bug fix the issue where the rngd thinks the kernel received sufficient
amount of entropy already although the kernel wants more

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

verification.payload:
tree 42be2ea5a3f076b71e6f66b6206b8a801720e21d
parent 0bfb546a4b6bbc4540f049f130e3a22f18e46f88
author Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1707204263 +0100
committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1707204263 +0100

Gracefully handling errors

The following improved error handling is added. This is needed to gracefully
operate with the ESDM (https://chronox.de/esdm) in edge conditions:

- handle write system call failures by deallocating and allocating the
entropy source which includes closing and opening the file descriptor to
/dev/random

- use proper variable types (ssize_t vs size_t) to avoid implicit casts

- bug fix the issue where the rngd thinks the kernel received sufficient
amount of entropy already although the kernel wants more

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

commit.message:
For SP800-90B ensure stable H_submitter

The H_submitter direclty depends on the selected oversampling rate.
The Jitter RNG API of jent_entropy_read_safe, however automatically
changes the OSR if there was a health failure. This implies that the
H_submitter changes.

When enabling the SP800-90B compliance mode, use jent_entropy_read
which fails directly on the health failure guaranteeing a stable
H_submitter.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

verification.payload:
tree f765f83810a6c30bdef151af66fdc03943356633
parent ade61a1548a2754d38f0c0c18f52b80d9a599420
author Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1691100687 +0200
committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1691100687 +0200

For SP800-90B ensure stable H_submitter

The H_submitter direclty depends on the selected oversampling rate.
The Jitter RNG API of jent_entropy_read_safe, however automatically
changes the OSR if there was a health failure. This implies that the
H_submitter changes.

When enabling the SP800-90B compliance mode, use jent_entropy_read
which fails directly on the health failure guaranteeing a stable
H_submitter.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

commit.message:
Determine minimum entropy threshold dynamically

Rather than hardcoding 1024, use the kernel's particular parameter,
which is how things will act that use poll() instead. This way sensible
defaults can change in relation to various other things.

Signed-off-by: Jason A. Donenfeld <Jason@zx2c4.com>
Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

verification.payload:
tree 9958c0a5c7a18f4e3cd0d937cb2c9a41d36ce55c

author Jason A. Donenfeld <Jason@zx2c4.com> 1643997489 +0100
committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1645391043 +0100

Determine minimum entropy threshold dynamically

Rather than hardcoding 1024, use the kernel's particular parameter,
which is how things will act that use poll() instead. This way sensible
defaults can change in relation to various other things.

Signed-off-by: Jason A. Donenfeld <Jason@zx2c4.com>

commit.message:
rngd: add --flags command line option

The command line option allows the caller to specify the integer value
that will be used as flags field when allocating the Jitter RNG. See the
jitterentropy(3) man page for the contents and definition of the flags
field. If this value is not set, the default is used.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

commit.message:
JENT: perform cache arithmetics only once

code path that is only executed once.

commit.message:
JENT: add replacement if cache sysconf flags not available

If the sysconf calls for getting the cache size are not available, read
the data out of SysFS. The SysFS files for the CPU0 (which should exist
in all cases) are accessed and read. The read operation attempts to read
up to 3 cache entries, searching for data and unified caches. This
covers the same functionality as the sysconf calls.

If errors occur, the read cache sizes are zero which is appropriately
handled by the Jitter RNG code base.

Reported-by: stoickish
Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

verification.payload:
tree da99ea3f111a2ae9a82839fcd6a556fca40830ee
parent 63488b32c3bc4cad6e07219e943ef3acb52b879f
author Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1630405022 +0200
committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1630405022 +0200

in all cases) are accessed and read. The read operation attempts to read
up to 3 cache entries, searching for data and unified caches. This

If errors occur, the read cache sizes are zero which is appropriately

commit.message:
Allocation error causes the rngd to exit

If an allocation error occurs, the rngd exits. This covers the power-up
health test error performed by the Jitter RNG noise source.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

tree c9055ea5cbc3796859adee382d773d5b8e5f50ef

committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615967452 +0100

Allocation error causes the rngd to exit

If an allocation error occurs, the rngd exits. This covers the power-up
health test error performed by the Jitter RNG noise source.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

commit.message:
Do not invoke RNDRESEEDCRNG when LRNG is present

The LRNG automatically triggers a reseed when new data arrives. Thus,
the invocation of the IOCTL is redundant.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

verification.payload:
tree 18f66c832728cd175b9b342624ae71fe8d6d9d38
parent e04589a2f6ae2b351569fee2e6af7684e810ef77
author Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615966740 +0100
committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615966740 +0100

Do not invoke RNDRESEEDCRNG when LRNG is present

The LRNG automatically triggers a reseed when new data arrives. Thus,
the invocation of the IOCTL is redundant.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

commit.message:
Add proper runtime health test error handling

If a runtime health test error is detected, re-allocate the Jitter RNG
to clear that error. This follows the requirement of the Jitter RNG
entropy source semantics.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

verification.payload:
tree 456238cca8a6e5ac43139f7d4cf24644ff2e686d
parent 9227212bc50d2bfcd4ae782d068f7030a1a7cb88
author Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615966470 +0100
committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615966470 +0100

Add proper runtime health test error handling

If a runtime health test error is detected, re-allocate the Jitter RNG
to clear that error. This follows the requirement of the Jitter RNG
entropy source semantics.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

commit.message:
Inject sufficient entropy into input_pool

When using the reseed IOCTL, it is invoked multiple times. Each time it
is able to drain up to 256 bits from the entropy estimator. Thus, the
entropy estimator must be increased by more than the number of IOCTLs
times 256 bits to ensure that the RNGD always ensures the estimator
rises. Otherwise an endless loop is triggered.

In addition, the invocation of the reseed IOCTL is only applied during
startup and when requested with the -s command line flag.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

verification.payload:
tree 4c8a08245f401c10d3f27ca09e243d527b9fe5ea
parent 96d855965d7fb53c32e30c5c2663f7f676b6f19e
author Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615802369 +0100
committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615802369 +0100

Inject sufficient entropy into input_pool

When using the reseed IOCTL, it is invoked multiple times. Each time it
is able to drain up to 256 bits from the entropy estimator. Thus, the
entropy estimator must be increased by more than the number of IOCTLs
times 256 bits to ensure that the RNGD always ensures the estimator
rises. Otherwise an endless loop is triggered.

In addition, the invocation of the reseed IOCTL is only applied during
startup and when requested with the -s command line flag.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

commit.message:
SP800-90B compliance support

The existing /dev/random implementation uses a SHA-1 operation whose
output is folded in half when generating data from the input_pool. This
implies that according to SP800-90B section 3.1.5.1, the n_out is 80
bits and that this operation can only deliver 80 bits at a maximum in
one invocation.

To support the case that the Jitter RNG provides SP800-90B compliant
noise data and that the output of /dev/random can be claimed to have
full entropy, the RNGD injects the data into the kernel with the
following strategy:

- If the LRNG is present, take no special precautions as this operates
  SP800-90B compliant.

- If the kernel is >= 4.17, chunk the data into 80 bit blocks, inject
these blocks into the kernel and after each injection use the
RNDRESEEDCRNG IOCTL to force the transport of the 80 bits of entropy
into the ChaCha20. This apporach implies that the ChaCha20 DRNG is
reseeded several times with 80 bits up to 256 bits of entropy and thus
can be claimed to have full entropy.

- If the kernel is < 4.17, the IOCTL is not available. Thus the data is
  inserted completely into the kernel. Yet, if the Jitter RNG shall
  operate SP800-90B-compliant with the -s command line flag, only 80
  bits of entropy are injected at
  all. The idea now is that either by adjusting the /proc values to
  cause /dev/urandom to always seed from the input_pool or by using
  /dev/random, after reading 80 bits from the kernel, the RNGD is
  triggered again. This way, the caller invocation ensures the chunking
  of the entropy data into 80 bits. This behavior implies, however, that
  the RNGD is always woken up when even one bit of entropy is missing
  from the pool. This implies that
  /proc/sys/kernel/random/write_wakeup_threshold needs to be set to
  a value around 4095.

In addition, this patch set fixes a bug where the invocation of the
RNDRESEEDCRNG causes the RNGD to drain the kernel entropy pool leading
to an endless loop.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>

verification.payload:
tree 21635d6b43df4c08ccf80f2e26e5f84686d1f76d
parent de1df5787a92f948e30cb1b339d2a36b900f7ab0
author Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615790417 +0100
committer Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de> 1615790417 +0100

SP800-90B compliance support

The existing /dev/random implementation uses a SHA-1 operation whose
output is folded in half when generating data from the input_pool. This
implies that according to SP800-90B section 3.1.5.1, the n_out is 80
bits and that this operation can only deliver 80 bits at a maximum in
one invocation.

To support the case that the Jitter RNG provides SP800-90B compliant
noise data and that the output of /dev/random can be claimed to have
full entropy, the RNGD injects the data into the kernel with the
following strategy:

- If the LRNG is present, take no special precautions as this operates
  SP800-90B compliant.

- If the kernel is >= 4.17, chunk the data into 80 bit blocks, inject
these blocks into the kernel and after each injection use the
RNDRESEEDCRNG IOCTL to force the transport of the 80 bits of entropy
into the ChaCha20. This apporach implies that the ChaCha20 DRNG is
reseeded several times with 80 bits up to 256 bits of entropy and thus
can be claimed to have full entropy.

- If the kernel is < 4.17, the IOCTL is not available. Thus the data is
  inserted completely into the kernel. Yet, if the Jitter RNG shall
  operate SP800-90B-compliant with the -s command line flag, only 80
  bits of entropy are injected at
  all. The idea now is that either by adjusting the /proc values to
  cause /dev/urandom to always seed from the input_pool or by using
  /dev/random, after reading 80 bits from the kernel, the RNGD is
  triggered again. This way, the caller invocation ensures the chunking
  of the entropy data into 80 bits. This behavior implies, however, that
  the RNGD is always woken up when even one bit of entropy is missing
  from the pool. This implies that
  /proc/sys/kernel/random/write_wakeup_threshold needs to be set to
  a value around 4095.

In addition, this patch set fixes a bug where the invocation of the
RNDRESEEDCRNG causes the RNGD to drain the kernel entropy pool leading
to an endless loop.

Signed-off-by: Stephan Mueller <smueller@chronox.de>
